comments.commentBody: Take the money and run.Boy is the Geran populace going to be irritated when they never see a payback of any of these monies.The Greek answer will be quite straight forward -We voted against this deal in a referendum-we knew we couldn't continue as such and pay back funds-it's your fault for making us take the money and it's all gone and our coffers are e.pty.Ouzo anyone?

The sad thing is that the German's did not promise anything. Debt relief is simple a maybe.... Besides being ousted by the German's for being to straight forward, Yanis Varoufakis had to leave because he probably knew Tsipras was going to cave.

On the surface the complete "flip-flop" by Prime Minister Tsipras seems mystifying.  One day he's against the continued austerity deal offered by Greece's creditors, walks away from it, gets his nation to say "No" to it, and, as the the French would say, voila, now he's all-in for it!  The only plausible explanation for this seemingly implausible behavior is that the French agreed to throw their weight behind Greece if they offered this proposal that includes a new negotiation based on the old deal and the hope of debt relief.  The alternative was the frightening prospect of the "Grexit" or exit from the Euro by Greece.  So, the Greeks with strong French backing have now made their move and its up to the still skeptical Germans and their eastern European allies to respond. Clearly, the stakes and the pressure on Germany have increased markedly and they now must enter into negotiations or risk a major rupture in the E.U. Moreover, it now will be hard for them to raise the pressure on Greece without seeming determined to force them out.  This may be "check" in the continuing E.U. chess game over Greek debt, but is it "mate"?

Tsipras and the Greek voters tried to play a big game of chicken and they lost.  They are unabashed deadbeats and the rest of Europe was right to refuse to pay for their excesses.  Tsipras blinked because he had to once he and his deadbeat compatriots got just a quick taste of what was definitely coming if they didn't.  I and many others are tired of hearing about them and tired of their childish brinkmanship.  Let them pull their act together, start paying and collecting taxes and otherwise reining in their profligate spending, or let'em leave the EU.  They voted for it so luzem gayen!!

My neck hurts from whiplash. First the Greeks resoundingly vote to reject austerity, and days later they're embracing it with open arms? This couldn't be a clearer display of the fact that the people running Greece haven't a clue what their doing. And neither do Greek voters.

I was sympathetic to the Greeks' plight before the referendum on Sunday. Now? I guess I just don't care.

The Germans, like many other peoples in Northern Europe, are not the inhuman bureaKrauts your stereotype would like to make believe. The simply want to have European co-citizens that can be trusted to follow the rules they all signed-up for, together and FREELY. The Greeks keep eroding the trust by demonstrating over and over again their unwillingness to keep the promises. As a consequence, their reputation keeps falling and reputation isreally what dictates credit conditions. They try to muddy the water by accusing ghostly bankers and supernormal speculation, but at he end of the the day they are only lucky that many European citizens are willing to spend some extra money to keep alive the ideal of a unite and peaceful Europe. And let's forget your mention of WWII debt, that has nothing to do with money borrowed and money returned.

Alexis Tsipras made a high-risk political chess move that will pay off. Not in benefit of the Greek population but rather for his own political ambition and career. His winning political hat trick play was to push the population, the banking system and the economy to the limit.

Tsipras aggressive actions -- intentionally or unintentionally -- did result into a run on bank deposits and a sudden stop of the economy. Under the gun and confused, the population overwhelmingly voted NO in the referendum as asked by youngster Alexis.

Then, in a surprise move he turns around and make a proposal to the eurozone creditors with much harsher and strict conditions than the previous accord under negotiation.

What is going on? what is the game plan? Alexis Tsipras won a high stake game. The opposition has been erased and he'll consolidate power and run the country for a long time.

Meanwhile, the Greek people will get what they want from the beginning. That is, to stay in the eurozone, be Europeans. However, the (false) Tsipras' promise of ending economic austerity will soon be forgotten. Times of honey and milk are over. From now on is to work hard for the euro and pay the national debt.

Some would, but with harsh conditions, no doubt. That is exactly what is happening. You have a neighbor whose house is falling apart, but you know he is unreliable. On he other hand, you really want him to fix the house, as it is in your neighborhood. You lend him the money with strict conditions. Isn't this what's happening?

NO folks, this is not a "betrayal" of the Tsipras government nor does this vote indicate the Greeks do not know what they are doing.

Because, anyone acquainted with a con artist knows that displays of theater and meaningless promises, such as a parliamentary vote, is exactly what an unscrupulous person would do to avoid paying one's debt.

And anyone who thinks otherwise is a clearly a fool.
Tell me of one country where wealthy tax evaders don't get away.... please don't say the US... Wall Street is full of them.

Best I can tell, even with these proposals, the referendum was not meaningless or "insane." It demonstrated that, whether the creditors like it or not, Tsipras and Syriza can rally the people, Greeks are rightfully fed up with austerity, and that Greece needs to be taken seriously in negotiations. Germany is finally, sort of, starting to admit the long-standing approach has not been working. The proposals at first are confusing, but demonstrate some pragmatism. Short of abandoning the Euro (politically costly but maybe a better long-term solution), it was likely the best Greece could get. I'm discouraged by how many comments rush to paint the Greeks as lazy, insane, incompetent, etc. Greece has plenty of problems, but with wealthy tax evaders and investment bankers taking advantage of the situation, there's plenty of blame to go around. I hope things get better for Greek people soon.

Perhaps this will buy Greece a little more time to figure out, in a practical step-by-step fashion, how it really is going to leave the Euro without closing down its banks.

There is no reasonable future for Greek citizens under the current austerity agenda, and it is time to get serious about an workable escape.

How would things play out after a return to the drachma? I get the devaluation aspect, since it would be a currency based on the full faith and credit of...just 2015 Greece. How would outcomes like increased production, job creation, economic activity and value creation follow?  I hope someone can provide the Econ 101 on this. Thanks in advance.

Soe why the referendum took place? What happened to the Greek pride?

Nevermind. I believe with this additional request for bailout Grece is just trying to extort additional money before its final exit. I wouldn't loan them a dime.

The downside of that scenario? As stated importing goods would become too expensive. Looking at goods that are crucial to a society i.e. oil and medicine, the EU would have to help during that period of transition. Either with subsidizing imports with money given to Greece or physically shipping crucial goods as some sort of humanitarian aid. Either way that would be much more preferably to me than transferring money through loans to pay back other loans which is what happens right now.

Greece would surely face a period of say one or two years of painful transition. But after that period it could look at an economy that is based on its productivity and able to exist on its own and not on loaned money. One day Greece could return to the Euro Zone actually meeting its requirements which it in fact never did.

The downside for the other Euro countries is that we would have to face the inconvenient truth that the loans granted to Greece would most probably have to be written off. Being a German tax payer I don’t say that easily. But despite what politicians keep claiming that there can be no debt release for Greece, at least nobody I know actually thinks that Greece will ever be able to repay its debts in the current scenario.

I am definitely not an econ specialist, but I thought that going back to the drachma would stimulate the Greek economy by making its products and tourism really cheap for people from outside the country ("hey, I can take a 2 week vacation in Greece for $800!) and so at least the economy would be stimulated and money would start flowing in. They would at least have some chance of making money, rather than just living to pay the EU debt and interest.

People would spend more to get less. Sales tax would be hiked to make up for lost revenues. More inflation and devaluation. People would have less to spend.
More doors to knock on before looting and civil war took over.

How would things play out after a return to the drachma? I get the devaluation aspect, since it would be a currency based on the full faith and credit of...just 2015 Greece. How would outcomes like increased production, job creation, economic activity and value creation follow?  I hope someone can provide the Econ 101 on this. Thanks in advance.

Or, as we say in espionage, the worst case is when we chase an amateur for we can never predict his moves. I suspect, though, that in all this game playing Tsipras hoped he would hear something concrete in public by the USA, China or Russia. Which brings us to a point never touched: what he discussed with president Obama in Washington last year this time around and what he discussed with Putin in two visits to Russia. Not to mention a delegation to China. It is weird that no light has been shed on those meetings. Maybe he had foreseen the dead arriving and knocked on every door he could under promise of secrecy.
The last paragraph says it all ... either the Greek government is tricking it's own people or it's tricking the the creditors. Who said it long ago ... beware of Greeks bearing gifts.

If you don't see what you like, just make it up -- as this commenter has:

"As far as I understand, the deal is absolutely not the same as last week : this time, it includes a significant forgiveness of Greece's debt, and asks for a financial commitment from the lenders to help Greece's growth, to help it get out of this spiral."

Not sure what "deal" you're talking about, but the ACTUAL deal includes no debt relief nor any such financial commitment. Nada. I expect there will end up being some debt relief, though much less than Greeks may anticipate. Almost certainly there won't be any "financial commitment from the lenders to help Greece's growth."
Wrong. The evidence shows that Lee did far more for Capote's writing (at least ICB)  than he did for hers. They did however support one another in their mutual desire to become writers.

I was thinking lazily about how Greece could create industries using Greek resources to make value added products to create wealth, and then I thought, hey, why don't they start an annual Olympics to bring in tourism and investment as well as interest in Greece year round. Actually, that's not a silly idea, after all, the Greeks invented the Olympics and I wouldn't have a problem with them taking back their rightly owned "Intellectual Property". I mean, look at what big business the Olympics are, being doled out every four years to high bidding cities that build infrastructure just for the single games events. I think the Greeks should reclaim their rightful Olympic notoriety and start the Greek annual Olympics. After all, we have the big businesses of Football and Baseball, and you know, they make billions.

"A capitulation after holding and winning the referendum? There are obvious problems with credibility..."

But if you're not concerned about credibility or integrity or any of those other silly virtues – as Tsipras almost certainly isn't – you'll count your effort as a success if you end up with any debt relief at all. The EU people haven't committed to any yet, but they probably will in the end. If so, Tsipras will have stumbled and lurched his way to a (slightly) better deal for Greece.

I doubt it will matter one way or the other, since it's hard to imagine that Greece will do anything but default on any deal that gets made, debt relief or not. But hope springs eternal, especially for prime ministers.

"I don't understand the raising of taxes in Greece. ... Why not start collecting taxes?"

Often Greeks who don't pay taxes are involved in activities that are hard for the government to monitor. In Greece's latest offer to the EU, most of the enhanced tax collection efforts seemed to be aimed at collecting more taxes from taxpayers who are already paying them.

@Thinker - What's sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander.

I don't understand why the German govt and Schaeuble, of all people, are taking such a hard line on the Greeks considering Germany's history with debt.
I believe that the cancellation of German debt in 1953 by Greece is a comment about hypocrisy and the moral pomposity evidenced by 2015 Germany.

A commenter asks:

"Why are we not talking about Germany's extensive outstanding debt? They borrowed billions in today's euros from Greece and have yet to pay them back."

Are you kidding?

At times lately, it's seemed to me that's ALL we talk about, as if cancelling a German debt in 1953 somehow absolves Greece of any obligation to repay loans in 2015 (at least to German debt-holders; it's never been entirely clear whether this absolution would apply also to debt-holders from other countries).

If Greece believes – or you believe on Greece's behalf – that Greece has some claim against Germany (even though it's been 62 years now), by all means assert that claim. But I fail to see how that affects Greece's obligation on its current debts.
It depends – does the brother live in Greece?

"the only "new" money Greece will get must be used to make payments on existing debt. If so, that's not really new money, since Greece otherwise wouldn't be making those payments. The EU will hand Greece the "new money," and Greece will hand it right back."

That is correct.

All the Greeks seem to have gained by the referendum was a rollover of more debt on better terms. That is no small thing, but it is not what they said they were seeking when they did the referendum.

If current reports are accurate, they'll still be mired in Depression with no hope of getting out, but they won't be pushed out of the Euro or EU.

I can't imagine acceptance of Depression as long term new normal will last. The government would be replaced. That won't win a vote. It didn't when FDR defeated Hoover, and it won't in Greece.

Unless I'm forgetting or misunderstanding the proposed new bailout, the only "new" money Greece will get must be used to make payments on existing debt. If so, that's not really new money, since Greece otherwise wouldn't be making those payments. The EU will hand Greece the "new money," and Greece will hand it right back.

If the EU (or creditors) are loaning Greece more than that, or if Greece is permitted to use any of the new loan for purposes other than debt payment – or if (as one commenter insists) creditors have made some "financial commitment" to jump-start Greece's economy – then the EU representatives must have checked their sanity at the door. But assuming none of that is true -- i.e. that Greece is to be given "new" money that can only be used to make debt payments that Greece otherwise would not make, this 53.5 billion Euro "new loan" doesn't really appear to be a new loan at all. Even so, I'm not sure I'd bother if I were the EU/creditors, since another Greek default strikes me as highly likely, but, on the other hand, nothing will really be risked in such a deal.

"But nope, let's keep shaming and blaming Greece for being bullied."

Do you have some free time next week? I need you to talk to the bank that holds my mortgage – it's a bully too.
I completly agree, the problem is the Greek government, totally inept, Fire the whole lot, and let Germany take conservator ship.

Comments like these make it seem very easy to get wealthy citizens to pay a fair share of their taxes. Time to look around at America's glass house, where Mitt Romney managed to squeeze himself into the 15% bracket— not to mention CEOs making billions of dollars, but avoiding taxes through clever dodges. Legal? Yes. But it still means not paying taxes, just as wealthy Greeks don't. Add to that government bailouts of banks too large to fail. Yet we look down our noses at the Greeks? Americans are just lucky enough to have sufficient resources to survive our own foolishness, although we, too, have too much poverty, while our safety nets are insufficient.

Yes, Greece needs to clean house, but it can't be done overnight and the austerity program has made things worse, probably not for wealthy, who have assets stashed outside Greece, but for the regular guy.

Nor can EU lenders cant expect to get anything back from Greece without writing off some of the debt or mitigating its terms. Tspiras did, in fact, manage to put that on the table. No small accomplishment. In a system where the Greek gov't cannot depreciate its currency, the EU has to take some responsibility for the problem, not just by lending money, but by helping the economy to get going. The economic downturn in 2008, by the way, was not the fault of Greek banks or real estate speculators.

Tspiras, by the way, has also highlighted the serious tensions in the EU between economic unity and political sovereignty.

The disheartening aspect of the current situation is the apparent inability of the Greed government to do any of the things that can put this country back on track toward success. They my promise to enforce tax collection and they may even be sincere in promising such, but their government is incapable of actually doing it. They could have been working on this over the last 5 years, but nothing has been done and noting will be done with the current cast of characters.

Along with the next bailout package there should be an instance that the entire Greek bureaucracy be fired and replaced from the ground up. Those despised Germans should be hired to organize the new government. They know how to get things done!
Beware of Greeks bearing gift horses.

what a clever approach!!!
I wonder what are you eating ang get that smart.....

Since when do the greeks ever see a penny of the bail out money...the money goes directly to the large banks in Germany and France. Even from the beginning Greece  actually received less then 10% of the bail out money.

Tsipras is a genius!!!!

He fooled most readers of the NYT into thinking Greece is an innocent victim of "Greedy lenders".

Then he fooled the citizens of Greece into thinking he'd fight for no austerity!
Then he fooled the EU members into giving him another $59b to use to pay their next loan payment (borrow money to pay off other borrowed money! Insane!)
Now he fooled the EU members that he's raise the "Tax rate" on the taxes he doesn't collect! Make the rate 10,000% - no matter - you don't collect it anyway! Pure genius!!

And - wait, here it comes - he'll sputter along for 18-24 months and then - my sides ache now --- then he'll stand up and say the EU are greedy thieves who should never have given him this money that they can't possibly pay back.

If you believe I am wrong - no problem, - take out your checkbook and write Greece your own bailout check. In fact, you can buy a Greek gov't bond right now that yields over 30%. Assuming they pay you.

What? You're not interested in that sort of bond? I didn't think you would be.
